What I did:

#!/bin/bash
for((i=31000;i<32001;i++))
do
    message=`echo "" | nc localhost $i -w 2 2>&1`
    # We have a successful connection
    if [[ $message != "localhost [127.0.0.1] $i (?) : Connection refused" ]]
    then echo "$i: success!"
         echo "$i: success!" >> good_ports.txt
    fi
done

This was the bash I used to iterate through all the ports and find which ones
were accepting connections. This showed me the two ports accepting connections
which were 31518 and 31790. I then used the command:

openssl s_client -connect localhost:<port-number>

This gave me no response for port 31518 but trying port 31790 gave me the
private key shown below. I saved this key in a file and had to use the following
command to log into the server:

ssh -o "IdentitiesOnly=yes" -i rsa.key bandit17@localhost

Where rsa.key is the file where I saved the key. Note that the header and footer
for the key are necessary. When prompted for a passphrase by ssh enter
nothing. I saved this key locally and created a bash alias of the command needed
for later. Note that when you log into the server remotely you need to connect
to port 2220 while if you're already on the machine you don't.

Edit: I learned that the password for each user is stored in
/etc/bandit_pass/<username>. So after logging into bandit17 with the ssh key you
can get the passworth with "cat /etc/bandit_pass/bandit17" and log in with it.
